story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Justgiving page.

We have decided to do Movember this year to raise as much money as we can for a great cause that has had a profound effect both on ourselves and a number of people close to us, Cancer Research UK. Only this year, we have lost a much loved uncle , Martin Cooper to lung cancer , and a close family friend David Aitchison is currently recovering from laryngeal cancer after beating it for the second time. Cancer research UK needs all the donations it can to hopefully find a cure for this evil disease especially given the huge delays in diagnosis following Covid.

Although we are only growing moustaches any donations at all are greatly appreciated and would mean the world to all of us! We will keep everyone updated on our terrible facial hair throughout the month and for anyone going through pain related to this horrible disease we are here to talk and provide any support we can!

charity.name: Cancer Research UK
eventName: George's YOLO Fund for Cancer Research
pageSummary: I am raising money because it saved my life this year
pageSummaryWhy: it saved my life this year
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  I was diagnosed with stage 3 bowel cancer in January 2022 at the age of 33 (and the year I got married!), and in the months following, had open surgery to remove a tumour in my colon, and eight rounds of chemotherapy.  I'm now in remission after being given the all clear in September and looking ahead to a bright future.

I'd never thought about what cancer research truly means until this year.  I took part in the Race for Life at the age of 14 which kick started my love of running, but to me it was a pretty pink t shirt and a scrumpled up sponsorship form being passed around my family. 

When I was diagnosed, a friend in the medical field told me if she got cancer, she'd prefer to get bowel or breast - they're the most common types of cancer and therefore get the most money pumped into their research.  Some clever person has done the research which enabled me to be given the drugs that saved my life.  That both blows my mind, and makes me wish I'd paid more attention in science.  

I'm not sure how someone could ever fully display their gratitude for the gift of life, but I'd like to use this page to try.  Please consider giving generously so that this vital research can continue, drugs can be developed and improved (woop for the person who invented my drug, Oxalyplatin meaning I didn't lose my hair) and save more lives.  

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: Cancer Research UK London Winter Run
story:
So here we are again....

Your support last year was amazing and really got me over that finish line. Lets do it again but smash last years target and raise some more money for Cancer Research UK. Running has changed my life and although i've only been doing it for about 2 years I feel like i've always been a runner now! I'm sure you all feel the same if you are one of my friends too as I never shut up about the benefits of running and how it has made a positive impact on myself and hopefully has inspired others to do the same. It's never too late. It's also given me the opportunity to get out there and raise some much needed funds for important charities over the past two years. Together we have raised over £2000. All this would not be possible with YOU!

So lets get this done and i'll run another 10k event and try and smash last years time. I can't promise I will do this but if St Johns ambulance don't pass me a sick bucket after finishing the race then I will see this as progress from my run in 2022 as that is exactly what they did! 🤣

Thanks again, your all awesome and I really appreciate your support especially with times as difficult for us all as they are now.

story:
Jake here, mild mannered vegetarian and family man.

I’m boxing to raise funds for Cancer Research - if I’d thought about this properly I’d have done a marathon, or some sort of hike but my knees aren’t that good… and I’m commîtes now. Unlike a marathon the suffering is hopefully over in 3 x 2 minute rounds. Also unlike a marathon coming second is not a desirable outcome.

For those of you who know me, you’ll appreciate that not being a fighter,  and I am nervous about this! So the motivation of raising money for a good cause is making this all worth while. Please donate it only takes a minute.

Official blurb below…

charity.name: Cancer Research UK
eventName: Hemel Hemstead / St Albans Ultra White Collar Boxing 10th December 2022
pageSummary: I am boxing because no fight is harder than cancer.
pageSummaryWhy: no fight is harder than cancer.
story:
On December 10th I’m going to be taking part in an incredible event to help raise money for Cancer Research UK in memory of my gorgeous aunt Nicola, who sadly lost her battle to cancer in February this year🕊 It’s also recently been the 2 year anniversary of my brothers death from suicide. So, I am fighting this battle for them, for my angels in the sky that couldn’t fight on anymore🤍 

I would really appreciate if you could please help me reach my fundraising goals…and HEY, it wouldn’t be for nothing! At the end of it you’ll get to see me get punched (or not get punched!) for 3 two minutes rounds🥊

When it comes to fundraising for Cancer Research, every penny really does count. I have included a picture of what your very own donations could be put towards to help with the groundbreaking research that Cancer Research UK does. One day we will live in a world free of cancer, we just have to work together!🌍

SO LETS BRING IT ON BABY…anyone who knows me well, knows that I’ve always been an avid boxing fan, and that having a fight of my own one day has always been at the top of my bucket list. SO...with raising money for Cancer Research UK at the same time, there is no better opportunity than this, and I’m putting in 110% of my efforts. This is not just a physical journey, but also a mental one too, and it’s a journey that I am so grateful to have the experience of being a part of❤️ 

Thank you so much to everyone for all of your support. If you are interested in the event itself or would like to come to the event please just let me know, here to answer any questions☺️

eventName: 100 Push Ups a day in November
story:
This November, 17 unlikely gentlemen will join forces to take part in The Push-Up Challenge for Cancer Research UK.

Through gritted teeth, sweat, tears and wobbly arms, they will be offering up over 50,000 push ups, to help raise funds for a fantastic cause. 

Everyday this November, each of our heroes will provide a relentless onslaught of push-ups with a target of 3k each over the month, totalling a whopping 51,000 push ups!

Please show your support to our push-up warriors and help them meet their fundraising target for Cancer Research UK.

Everyone has been effected by cancer in one way or another, so please dig deep and give generously.

Meet the team : 

Harris Thornton - AKA - Harry Squatter

Jack Smithson - AKA - Gaindalf

Joshua Abdelfatah - AKA - Elvis Pressley

Nathaniel Lloyd - AKA - Macaulay Bulkin

Jake Wood - AKA - The Abdominal Snowman

Andrew Bonnici - AKA - Gym Carey

Ben Hewitt - AKA - Dumbelldore

William Barr - AKA - Hans Swoleo

Sean Aquilina - AKA - Legdaylas

Richard Lovatt - AKA - Triple Bench

Rufus Morgan - AKA - Judi Bench

Thomas Hume - AKA - Humeongous Pectoral

William Waterhouse - AKA - Jonny Repp - AKA - Jacked Sparrow 

Seamus Roderigo Stanbury - AKA - Shamwise Gymgee’s The Brave 

Jorge Coyle - AKA - Lord Swoledemort

Gary Pogue - AKA - Push-Up Pogue

William Snaith - AKA - Brawn Connery

pageSummary: We are asking for donations because this was a cause close to Maureen’s heart.
pageSummaryWhy: this was a cause close to Maureen’s heart.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Maureen was diagnosed with metastatic melanoma and we lost her just weeks later. Having fought both breast cancer and previous melanoma, as well as losing her beloved husband and sister to cancer, her family want to do all they can to honour her fight and support other families. Although our family has experienced the tragedy of cancer, with your donation, we can help more people survive after their diagnosis. This would be the most wonderful way to honour our mum and all those we’ve lost. Thank you so much x

pageSummary: To help find the cure for cancer because cancer took Dad away from us all way too soon
pageSummaryWhat: To help find the cure for cancer
pageSummaryWhy: cancer took Dad away from us all way too soon
story:
David (Dave, Dad, Grandad) Villani

He was the kindest, most loving person I knew. He spent his life looking after his family and friends as they were his entire world. Dad would do anything for anyone and would be there in a heartbeat, be it a drive to see you, or one of his famous phone calls from his car.

Dad spent his entire life making people happy, supporting those who needed his help and was the worlds best 'problem solver'. Sadly we have lost him to the hardest problem in the world, cancer.

Dad wasn't a material man, he loved his random bits like his cars, generators and of course his tech but what he cared for most was spending time with those close to him, especially his wife and best friend Dionne.

As a result and to celebrate his legacy, I have set up this page with all donations going Cancer Research UK. This charities entire focus is to help find the cure for cancer and we all know that dad would want to crack this 'problem' and stop anyone else going through this horrible illness.

David (Dave, Dad, Grandad) Villani, loved by many, there for anybody, taken way too soon.
title: David Villani, a great husband, dad, grandad, brother and friend

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I little bit about why I am taking part in this event, and also a bit about myself.  

My name is Adam and i am 33 years of age, I have the most amazing family who support me in everything I do and I am so grateful for that, they  are my world. I have 3 of the most beautiful children bonnie-lea,roman and celia-Rae, my partner in crime sarah what would I do without you love.  you've given me the best things in life worth living for so thank you. 

The reason I am taking part in this event Is that I have lost close family members to this horrible disease whom I was close to. There's not a day that goes by we're I don't think of them. I am also doing this event as it means alot to myself & it is also to get myself fit and to lose weight  as I am borderline diabetic and suffer with high blood pressure, this is a great starting point for myself to be getting fit and maintaining this. I would like to thank all the people whom have help me and also all donations are really appreciated, thank you.

eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
the rec hub will be taking part in Save the Children's Christmas jumper day on Thursday 8th December 2022! 🎄🎅🏻

This year is extra special since the government have promised to match your donations - double the funds means double the fun! 

These donations will be used to improve the lives of children through better education, health care and economic opportunities as well as providing emergency aid in natural disasters, war and more. 

Just click the Give Now button above to donate. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our goal!

Thank you for taking the time to support a great cause 💙

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
Balfour Beatty are taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year we hope to raise £2,000! 

We appreciate the cost of living crisis is affecting all of our communities this year and we want to express that a small donation will go a long way as, if you donate between December 1st and March 1st the government have promised to match your donation*. Simply click the Give Now button above to donate £2 and the UK government will double it.

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

media.images.image.caption: NA
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Friday 9th November, for all our lovely customers in the taproom to take part with us! 
(Official date Thursday 8 December, so we'll be a little late)

This year, its going to be twice as good as ever before! That's because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*.Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day (early) - on Tues 06 Dec 2022. We will dress our children to impress that day as it is our Christmas Party too. 

Please upcycle existing festive clothing and donate to Save The Children in lieu of buying a new jumper. :)

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!



Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*.
Double the funds, double the fun!



Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!



So donate now and help us reach our target.



By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.



Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

media.images.image.caption: NA
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!



Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*.
Double the funds, double the fun!



Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!



So donate now and help us reach our target.



By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.



Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

media.images.image.caption: qrcode
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description: Save the Children exists to help every child reach their full potential. In the UK and around the world, we make sure children stay safe, healthy and keep learning, so they can become who they want to be.
charity.name: Save the Children
eventName: Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day 2022
story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

story:
We're taking part in Save the Children's Christmas Jumper Day on Thursday 8 December and this year, its going to be twice as good as ever before!

Thats because the government has promised to give the same amount as you give this Christmas Jumper Day*. Double the funds, double the fun!

Just click the Give Now button above to donate £2 (or more if you're feeling generous...) and the UK government will double it. We've also got our own QR code: just scan the code with your phone camera and donate to our team!

So donate now and help us reach our target.

By pulling on our Christmassy knits and donating, we'll be helping mums and babies stay healthy, and giving them the chance of the future they deserve.

Just £20 could buy antibiotics to help ten children beat malnutrition.

charity.description:
At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. To
donate, volunteer, raise money or campaign with us, call 0300 1000 200 or visit macmillan.org.uk
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: I am cycling the 532km from London to Paris because I want to help those affected by cancer.
pageSummaryWhat: I am cycling the 532km from London to Paris
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help those affected by cancer.
story:
Hi all!

They say almost everyone knows someone who is affected or impacted by cancer — well, this has been true for me from a very young age. My paternal grandmother passed away from Cancer before I was born. Back then, the correct diagnosis took time, and my family struggled with the expensive treatment suggested. The world didn’t have the right affordable technology to save her. 

Then, when I was 15 years old, we got the absolutely awful news that my father was diagnosed with Cancer too. However, due to the tremendous progress in cancer research and diagnosis as well as the financial and emotional support my family received (not to mention his own steady resilience), he was able to fight it off and is healthy today.

But if we want many others to be so lucky and beat the ‘emperor of all maladies’, we need to support people through the social, emotional and practical impact cancer can have.

Today, more than 3million people are living with cancer in the UK and the WHO estimates that nearly 1 in 6 deaths globally were due to cancer last year. To fight cancer, we not only need to invest in research and treatment, but also need to support those living with cancer and their families across every stage of their cancer journey.

Given the cost of living crisis, extreme action is needed as 1 in 4 people living with cancer in the UK feel that they just ‘can’t afford life’, according to Macmillan Cancer Support. So I’ll be cycling from London to Paris in next July to raise money for Macmillan, who provide vital cancer services, research, and campaign to achieve better cancer care, and support the cancer workforce as well as giving emotional, financial, and practical support to the patients and families of those suffering from the disease.

Given that I didn't even own a road bike until earlier this summer, I am sure that cycling the 532km from London to Paris will definitely be a challenge. But this is personal for me (as I am sure it is for many) and I am committed to give my all to make sure I am ready between now and July, putting in the hours come rain, snow or shine so I can partake in what will be the most physical challenge of my life so far. 

In return, I would be grateful if you could support me by donating and supporting the fantastic work that Macmillan Cancer Support do.
title: Nishad's London to Paris Cycle Ride for Macmillan Cancer Support

pageSummary: I’m running The London Marathon 2023 & fundraising because of the amazing work they do.
pageSummaryWhat: I’m running The London Marathon 2023 & fundraising
pageSummaryWhy: of the amazing work they do.
story:
In April 2023 I will be taking on the massive challenge of running The London Marathon. I was lucky to gain a ballot place to run the 2022 London Marathon, and I’m so excited to have the opportunity to do it all again in 2023, this time raising funds for Macmillan Cancer Support.

Macmillan is here to help everyone with cancer to live life as fully as they can, by providing emotional, physical, practical and financial support.

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan gives people with cancer everything they’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are Macmillan’s worries. Macmillan’s doing whatever it takes. But without your help, Macmillan can’t support everyone who needs them. Please give what you can. Your support will make a massive difference and will really help me get to the finish line 😊

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe, JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.description:
At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. To
donate, volunteer, raise money or campaign with us, call 0300 1000 200 or visit macmillan.org.uk
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Here we go! I’ve got my running trainers on, ready for the 2023 London Marathon. This will be no Sunday morning jog, but I am excited, if not a little terrified, to be involved in this renowned event.

The London Marathon isn’t just a huge day in the running racing calendar, it’s an opportunity to raise awareness and support UK charities, which is why I’m running for Macmillan Cancer Support.

Cancer remains the second-leading cause of death worldwide and there are more people than ever before living with this cruel disease, including people close to my heart.

I’m running for my family members who have been, or continue to be, affected by cancer. My paternal grandparents were diagnosed with breast and bowel cancer and today, my nanny, aunty and uncle all live with the disease. These are the family members that have inspired me to take on the toughest challenge of my life!

Luckily, my family have a strong support network, but not everyone does, which is where MacMillan come in.

Macmillan is one of the largest British charities which provides specialist health, information and financial support to people affected by cancer. It also looks at the social, emotional and practical impact that cancer can have, and campaigns for better cancer care.

I'd like to raise £2,500 for Macmillan Cancer Support, so any donation, big or small, is greatly appreciated and will directly go towards funding Macmillan Grants.

Thank you,
Luke

eventName: In memory of Aunty Pat Blair
pageSummary: Colombia Charity Trek for Macmillan Nurses. because In memory of Aunty Pat
pageSummaryWhat: Colombia Charity Trek for Macmillan Nurses.
story:
We are a group of friends from the U.K. Travel Industry, getting together to raise money for charity.   

To raise money in the past some of us have climbed Kilimanjaro, Machu Picchu and to Everest Base Camp.  Now it’s the steamy jungles of Northern Columbia in South America, where we are undertaking a trek to La Ciudad Perdida - The Lost City, located in the high mountains to the south of Santa Marta, Colombia.

This is an arduous trek in high altitudes, with high temperatures, mountains, and rivers in wild countryside. It’s a maximum difficulty trek.  No one is going to sponsor us for a walk in the Park!  

During the trip we will be making a movie to show our sponsors when we get home, with regular blogs and P.R. along the way.

We were inspired to do this journey when we all met during the Institute of Travel and Tourism Conference in Istanbul in June 2022.

Thanks for considering sponsoring us.  Every penny we raise will go to the charities.  

We are all paying our own way for the whole trip to South America and back.  

We are grateful to G Adventures for giving our group special rates for the trip as their contribution to our cause.....thanks Brian!
title: Colombia Charity Trek

pageSummary: I am taking on a new routine to help out! because they work to make cancer worries lighter
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking on a new routine to help out!
pageSummaryWhy: they work to make cancer worries lighter
story:
A daily fitness routine has always sounded impossible to me. Anyone who knows me can verify that statement. So here I am, ready to do daily yoga to support the amazing work that Macmillan do to help people in need. They  never give in on their mission, in spite of the energy crisis and the continuously rising cost of living. Imagine living through that, and suddenly being diagnosed with cancer. Macmillan are here to help you go through this. You’re not alone.

Macmillan is a charity that  gives people with cancer everything they’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are Macmillan’s worries. Macmillan’s doing whatever it takes, so here’s my little bit too. But without your help, Macmillan can’t support everyone who needs them. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and escurre. Your details are safe, JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

pageSummary: I am raising funds for mcmillan in memory of Clive because He was such a kind, genuine,  gentle soul.
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising funds for mcmillan in memory of Clive
pageSummaryWhy: He was such a kind, genuine,  gentle soul.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I met Clive briefly but he passed from mylodyplastic syndrome. He seemed such a kind-hearted, caring soul who was young at heart. Clive left behind a very loving family. We raise money every year for mcmillan by having a Halloween display for the whole neighbourhood and anyone else who wants to join in and this year we are making it bigger and better. The last time I met Clive we spoke of Halloween and he shared memories with me of his last Halloween and how much he enjoyed it. So this year, we would like to honour his memory by giving everyone a night to remember.  More research into this could help benefit so many people. Please, please consider donating to clives page.

story:
Santander are proud to be working in partnership with Macmillan Cancer Support, and we are so excited to be supporting them through our annual Team Up Challenge.

Were asking Santander colleagues to team up together to complete a 20-mile distance in whatever way they like, all to raise money for Macmillan. Whether its together or a relay, backwards or in fancy dress, we want you to complete the challenge your way so we can support the more than 3 million people in the UK living with cancer.

Macmillan will do whatever it takes to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can. If youre diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They will move mountains to help you live life as fully as you can. And they dont stop there. Macmillan are going all out to find ever better ways to help people with cancer, helping to bring forward the day when everyone gets life-transforming support from day one.
title: Santander IA Team Up 2022 page

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. In loving memory of Dad we are looking to raise funds for Macmillan Cancer Support. They were such an amazing source of help and care for both Mum and Dad during his cancer and we'd love to raise funds in Dad's name so that his memory can contribute towards other families being able to benefit from the invaluable work that Macmillan do. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Reflection - In less than 2 weeks I will have made it to the 50's club and I keep being asked what am I doing.

Well if you know me then you will know I am happy just to go for a walk. Happy because I have made it to 50 when so many people don't make it. 

So on my hike last week  I thought what would happen in these tough times if I set up a Charity page called Hike for 50.

Would I raise 50 pence, £50, £500 or even £1972 for a charity that is close to my heart. 

So in memory of my beautiful sister in law and a beautiful friend
who did not see her 35th birthday.

To all the beautiful people in my life who have got through it and are loving life or the amazing and strong people who are are still going through treatment this hike is for ALL of you.

Yes I am part of the 1972 club and I will be hiking on my 50th. 

I fully appreciate it tough out there but it even harder for charities so if you can donate that great and if you cannot that is fine too x
title: Hike for 50

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan gives people with cancer everything they’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are Macmillan’s worries. Macmillan’s doing whatever it takes. But without your help, Macmillan can’t support everyone who needs them.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe, JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.


I am running the London marathon in memory of my grandad who passed away in 2020 he was diagnosed with prostate cancer however he sadly passed. He was a very prominent figure in my life and got to witness many milestones. I cannot thank him enough for all he has done for me and I would not be the same person I am today without him. He left a massive hole in my life and macmillan where there for me and my family when we needed it the most. 

For that I am forever grateful and would love to support them in helping others going forward.


Please support me and this amazing cause any donations welcome.

pageSummary: I am collecting because I would like to honour the memory of my Nan
pageSummaryWhy: I would like to honour the memory of my Nan
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My Grandmother Anne Lewis lost her battle with cancer Sunday 23rd October. Rather than flowers the family have asked for donations to The Red Cross.

My grandmother Anne (or Nanny Annie as we used to call her) was an extraordinary woman who raised a big family who all love and support each other. We're one of those weird families who actually like each other.

We are all being strong and holding each other up whilst we all deal with our grief. We will get through this together, which is what she would have wanted.

Please consider donating to such a fantastic cause and help honour the memory of my Nan.

Thank you

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Every child deserves the best possible chance to rebuild their life after abuse

eventName: Ptarmigan Media Thames Walk for the NSPCC
story:
Childhood should be a time to dream, but Covid-19 has robbed many more children of that opportunity. Since the pandemic and lockdowns: 1 in 6 children now struggle with their mental health - up from 1 in 9. The NSPCC has seen a 3x increase in children talking to Childline about sexual abuse within the family. And, a 53% in domestic violence.

We know that the right support at the right time can prevent both abuse and mental health problems from derailing the rest of a child's life.

£4 answers a call to Childline from a child suffering in a silence. £25 covers an hour of therapy - rebuilding lives after abuse. Every penny you raise can help put a child's life back on track. Every penny you raise is helping give thousands of children the support they need to dream of a brighter future.

pageSummary: Raising money by running a half marathon because all children deserve to be safe
pageSummaryWhat: Raising money by running a half marathon
pageSummaryWhy: all children deserve to be safe
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be running a half marathon on 18th December 2022 in Stowmarket called Let it Stow. I haven't completed a half marathon for a few years but I am using this as motivation to get running again and to raise some money for an important charity called NSPCC - The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

I will also be giving up alcohol until I have completed the race  :)

I would appreciate any support you can give to raise money for such an important charity. That one donation could be the difference between a child suffering or a child receiving support, care and finally feeling safe. Every penny counts and is greatly appreciated. 

About the charity

NSPCC provide services that help children who've been abused, protect children at risk, and find the best ways to prevent child abuse from ever happening.

This charity is helping vulnerable children who could be dealing with the below

  • Depression
  • Suicidal thoughts
  • Physical and/or Sexual Abuse
  • Emotional abuse
  • Neglect
  • Loneliness
  • Criminal and/or Sexual exploitation
  • Trafficking and modern slavery
This Christmas, Childline is expecting a call from a child every 25 seconds.

Every child has the right to a safe and loving home. 🖤

Please share if possible with friends and family 

*Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.*

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be running the MK festival of running on march 12th 2023 at 9.50am at Xscape.

I have never done a half marathon before so this will be a huge challenge, i managed a 10k in under a hour in april 2022 so ive put myself down to do the half marathon in 2 hours! Lets hope i can achieve this 🙏😅

Whilst i love running i was not looking to do a half marathon but a friend roped me into it (Dave) daves actually running with me and my mate sam, the 3 of us have put a 2 hour time and we are all competing against eachother.

I love to support charities, with every running event i have done, i have raised money for some amazing charities and i wish to do it again but this time for the nspcc.

Nspcc ( National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children) is a service that help children who've been abused, protect children at risk and find the best ways to prevent child abuse from ever happening.

I would really appriciate your support and a donation to this incredible charity would be amazing if you can. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thankyou 🙏❤️🙌

pageSummary: I am running the 2023 London marathon because I want to fundraise to support vulnerable children
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the 2023 London marathon
pageSummaryWhy: I want to fundraise to support vulnerable children
story:
In August 2021 our family life changed forever as Nick and I welcomed our amazing adopted son into our lives. He was taken into care in 2020 at the age of just 5. Already in his short life he had been through a level of trauma and loss not really experienced by most adults. Our little dude will likely need therapeutic support in the future to support him in managing what he has been through.

I’d like to give something back to an amazing charity who support both children and families in crisis. The work they do to safeguard children is amazing. As a professional working within a school, the work the NSPCC do to support ongoing child protection training is also priceless. 

This will be my 4th marathon. I’m not giving myself a target time but my main aim is to enjoy it and raise some money! 

Thank you for your support with my 2023 London Marathon JustGiving challenge!My page donations will be sent direct to the NSPCC in a fast and secure way. Its efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. Let's do this!

pageSummary: running the London Marathon 2023 because my dad cared deeply about helping children
pageSummaryWhy: my dad cared deeply about helping children
story:
Thank you for visiting my JustGiving page. 

As some of you may know, my dad was diagnosed with a rare neuroendocrine cancer in January 2022 and sadly passed away in May. I thought long and hard about which charity I wanted to support through my London Marathon fundraising and the NSPCC felt like the best fit to serve in his memory. My dad cared deeply about helping children and particularly children who had faced abuse. He had hopes of building an orphanage in his home town in Kashmir, Pakistan, but sadly he never got the chance to fulfil that dream. I've chosen to fundraise for the NSPCC in his memory to support a cause he cared so much about and contribute to change that he would have wanted to see.

pageSummary: I'm running the Royal Parks Half because every childhood is worth fighting for ❤️
pageSummaryWhat: I'm running the Royal Parks Half
pageSummaryWhy: every childhood is worth fighting for ❤️
story:
So here I am again - taking on another Royal Parks Half Marathon. This time I've set myself a huge target when it comes to the time I want to complete the 13.1 miles in. I'm determined to rise to the challenge and of course am proud to raise as much money as I can for my chosen charity at the same time.

I thought long and hard about who I would love to represent this time around, and for me as a Mum and someone who works in Education it was an easy choice...I am so so proud and honoured to be representing the NSPCC in 2023.

The reason for me is simple - EVERY child has the right to grow up feeling safe, loved, protected and happy. No excuses. No exceptions. 

You have all been SO amazing when it comes to supporting my running and the charities I have represented over the years. I honestly couldn't have done any of it without you all. 

I'm forever grateful...here WE go again ❤️

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: NSPCC
pageSummary: I am fundraising because God made me to be an advocate for abused children.
pageSummaryWhy: God made me to be an advocate for abused children.
story:
I am so honored to be running the 2023 London Marathon on April 23 to support the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. It is a beautiful collaboration between 2 passions in life that fuel my fire. My page donations will be sent direct to the NSPCC in a fast and secure way. It's efficient, saves time and cuts costs for the charity. 

Life is short. I believe that we should dream big and make our lives count! I have been a Court Appointed Special Advocate since 2020 to help abused and neglected children in Houston. I'm a mom of 4 boys and I pray for their safety & protection daily. Running is another passion of mine that has given me so much more than I could ever explain (especially friendships and restored physical and mental health). I ran my first marathon with Team in Training to support the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in 2009. It was a wonderful experience and that race got me "hooked." Many years and miles later, I have a new goal. I want to run all 6 of the Abbott World Majors Marathons. I've run 2 of them, meaning I have "2 stars" - Boston and Chicago. The London Marathon is next on my list. After I run Houston in January, the London Marathon will be my 20th Marathon, my 1st international marathon and my "3rd star in the Abbott World Majors Marathons." As one of my favorite 80's songs states, I'll be "halfway there" and I'm always "Livin' on a Prayer." Thank you for supporting me in my goal to fight child abuse and my dream to run the 6 World Majors Marathons. It means so much! XO, Lindsay

pageSummary: I am running the London marathon in 2023 because I'm passionate about protecting children from harm
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the London marathon in 2023
pageSummaryWhy: I'm passionate about protecting children from harm
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my page and read my story. 

As a keen runner, I have wanted to take part in the London marathon for as long as I can remember. The enjoyment of being part of something, so challenging but life affirming, is irresistible to me.

This year I am putting my feet where my mind is and fulfilling this ambition, but with a very special something to spur me around the 26.2 miles.......I am so proud to be raising money for the National Society of Prevention of Cruelty to Children. 

There are so many worthy charities that I thought about supporting, but as soon as I thought about the NSPCC, I realised it was the right fit for me. Having suffered trauma as a child, I know that the NSPCC are there to help those that need them.

I am a mother of three boys, 12, 10 and 8, the wellbeing of my children is my raison d'etre.  I use the NSPCC website for tips on keeping my boys safe online, also for fun practical ways of singing about keeping themselves safe - we love Pantosaurus - If you haven't met him give him a search.

I am also a Police Officer and over the last 20 years, I have come into contact with children who have suffered online, physical and emotional abuse. I have made referrals to the NSPCC who have devoted support to these children, families and schools to prevent harm and help children who have been abused.

Thanks for reading, and more importantly thanks for supporting ❤

charity.description:
The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity working in 130 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and
Community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, homeless people, all adult victims of modern slavery and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction. Alongside our work in the UK, The Salvation Army International Projects Office works with communities around the world to support and empower them to defeat poverty and injustice. Our development projects are created and implemented in partnership with communities to enable them to build a better life and future for themselves. 
The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity in England (214779), Wales (214779), Scotland (SC009359) and the Republic of Ireland (CHY6399)
charity.name: The Salvation Army
pageSummary: Please help us raise funds because every family deserves a Christmas
story:
Every year at Christmas, The Salvation Army in Stirling provides toys, gifts and food for families and the elderly who are in financial difficulty.  These children are referred to us by professional support workers both in health and education settings and social services.  Last year we provided Christmas to 150 families in Stirling.  This year we expect this number to be far higher!

The Salvation Army's Christmas Present Appeal makes a huge difference to hundreds of children across Stirling by making sure they receive a gift on Christmas Day instead of missing out.  This year with the effects of the Cost of Living Crisis, we especially need your help to ensure no child is neglected this Christmas.  

Could you help us make Christmas Special for those who have little or
nothing on the table this Christmas?  The Salvation Army in Stirling is also raising money to ensure that the poorest families can receive a Christmas dinner this year.  Through our Meal Appeal we aim to provide Christmas dinner for pensioners and families who otherwise may not be able to afford a Christmas meal.  A donation of £20 will provide them with a 3 course Christmas meal & a small gift.

Be a Star this Christmas and help those that need it most.
title: Christmas Present & Meal Appeal

charity.name: The Salvation Army
story:
The Salvation Army provides specialist support to protect and care for all adult survivors of modern slavery in England and Wales through a government contract which was first awarded in 2011 and extended in 2021.

Our care of survivors of modern slavery has highlighted the exploitation of both men and women in a variety of ways including forced labour on farms, in factories, on building sites, in car washes, nail bars, and criminal activity such as cannabis farming as well as sexual exploitation and domestic servitude, some suffering domestic abuse. 

The Salvation Army provides and coordinates Safe Houses, and outreach support for such survivors. Each resident receiving Salvation Army support is respected and valued as an individual and the support they are offered is holistic and tailored to meet individual needs.

eventName: Donna's Sky Dive for The British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am doing a sky dive because to help raise money and awareness
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing a sky dive
pageSummaryWhy: to help raise money and awareness
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. 

£24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me. Thanks!

I am doing this mega challenge with friends and hoping to raise awareness for BHF. I will be jumping on Sunday 30th October from 15,000ft at the Black Knights Sky Diving Centre in Lancaster.

We appreciate any donations, no matter how much. 

I will be putting up a video of the jump next Sunday evening!
title: Donna's Sky Dive for The British Heart Foundation

charity.description: Heart and circulatory diseases are the world’s biggest killers. That’s why the British Heart Foundation exists. By funding research, we can help find treatments and cures that could save lives. With your donations and the awe-inspiring science we fund, we make science fiction a reality, together.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Hi everyone, I've decided to go vegan for the month of November to raise money for the British Heart Foundation, in memory of my Nanaji, Maghar Singh Diocee.

November is an important month for me because it is the month of my Nanaji's birthday. Furthermore, the research conducted by the charity has helped create treatments for my loved ones, including my Nanaji, Great Grandma, Nani and a good friend of mine, who have all experienced some form of cardiovascular disease, which is why the British Heart Foundation is a charity that I hold close to my heart ;)

The British Heart Foundation funds around £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseased and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They have helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but every day hundreds of people lose their lives. Its only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures.

I would appreciate it if you could donate and share this page. Thanks for your support!

Finally, I'd like to thank my friend Ajit for supporting me in this challenge. She's also going vegan for a month in support of Dementia UK, so check that out too. (She really said YNWA 🌚)

https://www.justgiving.com/page/ajit-kaur-landa-

pageSummary: Our page is in memory of our beautiful soul because He sadly passed away on 29/9/2022
pageSummaryWhat: Our page is in memory of our beautiful soul
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Dad was known to most people as Sandy, until last week I had no idea why.  It seems there were a lot of Richard’s in the RAF so, because of his red hair, he earned the name Sandy.  Until the kids were teenagers they had no idea his real name was Richard.  Although he had a few good nicknames including “Froll”.

Dad suffered heart problems for many years and a while ago we were told he had heart failure.  As most know this is a lifetime condition with no cure. Dad had several spells in hospital but they couldn’t do much to help his condition. 

On 27 September we were told he also had lung cancer. He went into hospital extremely ill on 28th September and passed away from heart failure at 3pm.  The doctors managed to resuscitate him long enough for us to spend some time with him.  Those few hours we are all truly grateful for. We got chance to tell him how loved he was and how he’d made all our lives that bit better. 

On 29 September at 11am Dad fell asleep and his heart stopped.  Although he had cancer, we feel his heart was the thing that took such a beautiful soul from us. 

For this reason we had flowers from immediate family and asked for donations to be sent to British Heart Foundation.  For those unable to do it on the day, and who would like to pay tribute to him, we’ve set up this page. 

Thank you everyone for the cards and kind words we’ve all had in the past month as a family we feel grateful for the love you’ve shown us. 

Goodnight God Bless Aged P we will all miss you always ❤️

story:
The gals have decided to challenge themselves to run the Chester Zoo 10K - dusted off the trainers and got off the sofa!

Also, it is such a great way to raise awareness (+hopefully a few pounds) for a charity which we are passionate about - the British Heart Foundation (BHF). We fully support the work of the charity, particularly their lifesaving research and their excellent free online resources.

If you have any spare cash, please consider donating. More importantly, if you have never been taught or need a reminder, please take a few moments to look at the BHF resources on how to do CPR, where to find your nearest defibrillator and how to use it.

 ✨Ultimately these are life saving super hero skills ✨

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are raising money for the British Heart Foundation in memory of Jeremy Eatough; our much loved colleague and friend. 

Jeremy retired in September having worked at the University of Wolverhampton for 33 years, 16 of those were spent in the Department of HR & Leadership, later the Department of Management and Leadership.  He was a thoughtful, gentle man with a renowned sense of humour.

Sadly Jeremy didn’t get much time to enjoy retirement and our thoughts are with his family and friends at such a sad time. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: I am running a marathon because they help people live well with heart conditions.
pageSummaryWhy: they help people live well with heart conditions.
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. It's so easy to take our hearts for granted. It's there beating away keeping us & our loved ones alive. And then...

...it can stop! Sometimes with no warning! That's what happened to my Dad & several of my friends' Mums & Dads. Their hearts stopped & suddenly they were gone. Whilst it may be 'a lovely way to go' in that it's quick, it's painful for us who are left behind. 

But it's not all bad news. Thanks to the BHF my Mum lives a full life with a heart condition. And many others do too, for which I'm truly grateful. 

So I'm exercising my heart (safely!) by extending my running & challenging myself to complete a Marathon on 12th November 2022 at Carver Barracks, Saffron Walden and hopefully not come last! Who needs toenails anyway? But...we all need our hearts.

I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation remembering my lovely Dad & to say "THANK YOU for my lovely Mum". I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thank you so much.

Rather than use the prize, I asked both Marmo and the raffle organisers if I could re-raffle the prize and raise more funds for the same charity.

So I've picked up a few extra prizes along the way..

Each entry is £5 each - please leave your email address so I can follow up with prizes.

charity.name: Unicef UK
pageSummary: I am raising money for children in Yemen
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money for children in Yemen
story:
Hi,

My name is Nicholas Wasunna, I work for UNICEF, having been posted in a number of duty stations I am currently posted in Yemen. I see on a daily basis how tough things are for the children here in the midst of the ongoing conflict. UNICEF are delivering some really great projects and initiatives which are making such a big difference in the lives of children here. In Yemen a child dies every 10 minutes from preventable causes.

This is such vital work and I want to support them as much as I possibly can … so I have decided to run the New York marathon on 6 November to try and raise more funds. I know that times are hard for many, particularly at the moment, so would greatly appreciate any donations people felt able to make. I feel somewhat daunted about taking on the marathon but feel really motivated knowing that every penny I raise will go directly to helping children that truly need it. 

Thank you so very much.

Nick.

story:
Ello, running a half marathon in a couple weeks lol. Initially just did this cos I've wanted to for ages and thought it'd be a fun challenge and then was like well why not try raise some money for something worthwhile in the meantime ey?!

Just over 2 years ago with some wonderful friends i walked 7 marathons in 7 days to raise money for Unicef specifically to help the humanitarian crisis in Yemen - Walk 7 for Yemen. Loads of stats and details on our insta if you'd like to have a look @Walk7forYemen. It was wild ngl. So I'm just hoping to add to what was raised before, even if it's literally a fiver! I know times are tough for everyone (cost of living innit), so any pennies you've got to spare would be amazing! Or if you have nada but wanna share this link to others, or come watch me lap Battersea park 8.5 (?!?!) times with a bright red face please do! 

thank you thank you, much lovin x

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: UNTHA UK names Marie Curie as charity of the year
story:
Each year, UNTHA UK makes a generous donation to a different worthy cause – usually around Christmas time. But this year, determined to make more of a phased impact, the company will band together over the coming months and dig deep for a charity committed to providing care and support to people living with any terminal illness, and their families.

From sponsored treks and bike rides to corporate events and bake sales, the team will cover all bases in its fundraising mission. A busy calendar of activities will be unveiled over the upcoming weeks, with something for each team member to get stuck into.

Following a company vote which invited every colleague to nominate their chosen beneficiary, Marie Curie stood out as the clear favourite among the group.

The organisation holds a special place in many of the team members’ hearts, including sales coordinator, Sarah Murray: “When my father was receiving palliative care, the Marie Curie nurses couldn’t do enough for us as a family. We will never be able to pay them back for the support they offered us when we needed it most, but UNTHA’s fundraising will allow me to say thank you and shine a spotlight on the amazing work they do.”

Managing director Marcus Brew added: “At UNTHA UK, we know that company success is about far more than commercial achievements – it’s also about the positive impact you have on the world around you,” explains managing director Marcus Brew. “We’re passionate about giving back to those who need it — and often such fundraising activities can bring the team closer together as a result. We’re looking forward to getting started for such a worthy cause.”

Marie Curie is the UK’s leading end of life charity, providing frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line, and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of death and bereavement.

Follow UNTHA UK on social media to watch the team’s fundraising endeavours unfold:

Twitter

LinkedIn

As many of you will know, our wonderful friend, Mike Whyman lost his brave battle with cancer recently. Mike was a kind, caring, lovely and hilarious person who enriched our lives just by knowing him. During his illness he, and his family received brilliant care and support from Marie Curie, in particular the Cardiff and The Vale Hospice in Penarth- commonly known as Holm Towers. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We  are raising money for Marie Curie who provided support to our mother who was caring for our father, Narindra. Night sitting nurses gave much needed respite to our mother. Being able to have a good night's sleep whilst our father was being cared for overnight allowed her to provide the care she wanted to give to her husband during the rest of the day. We are grateful for the help that our mother received from the Marie Curie night sitting nurses and we hope this money will go towards other people receiving this help. Please help us raise money for this important charity.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Mum was a huge supporter of Marie Curie and the work they do for people and families affected by terminal illness.  One sunny morning in 2013, we all embarked on a 10km walk around Catton Hall in memory of Gran Elsie, Tina's mum.  We remember with fondness as we walked through the countryside chatting, laughing and being entertained by the children.  This was when mum was at her happiest, surrounded by her family.  

Caring for people was in mum's DNA.  Having spent over 40 years in nursing, it is no surprise that Marie Curie became an important part of her life.  Always putting others first, mum just wanted to brighten up people's day, whether that was with a kind word or just a hand to hold. 

Thank you for all your lovely messages, kind words and wonderful memories of mum.  Your support is hugely appreciated and comforting during this very difficult time.

Love and Best Wishes

Rachelle, Nick, Dad and families
