story:
"You must never be fearful about what you are doing when it is right” - Marie Curie 

Wise words from a lady who made her life’s work to revolutionise medicine. One of her many successes directly linked to the treatment of cancer. 

Her work and legacy remains a global treasure and when asked to take on the challenge of climbing Mount Kilimanjaro to raise money towards keeping her legacy alive (Marie Curie - end of life charity) I simply could not refuse. 

Living on the Isle of Man, I understand the importance of supporting the wonderful and vital IOM charities too and, with this in mind, I pledge to personally donate.  Marie Curie do an amazing job but I personally had first hand experience of the fantastic work Hospice Isle of Man does for our local community. My financial charity target for Marie Curie is £1,225 so if I reach this target I will personally donate £1,225 to Hospice Isle of Man in true Isle of Man local support. 

I know the challenge that awaits in January 2023 will test my resilience, strength and fitness but knowing what I am climbing for and the difference it will make is all the motivation I need.
title: Jodie's page for Kilimanjaro climb 2023

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last.

Marie Curie believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how.

Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: I am trekking to Mt Everest Base Camp in Mar-23
pageSummaryWhat: I am trekking to Mt Everest Base Camp in Mar-23
story:
The idea of doing this came from a young age as my dad made this very trek to base camp in 2004. He always spoke of what an amazing trip it was, with so many memories and stories. I never thought I'd have this same opportunity until I was invited to an information evening at uni and came away extremely tempted to take the plunge. After a great deal of deliberating and being told to "stop analysing and just book it" by my dad, I thought: "what the hell!"

My university chose to raise money for Marie Curie. I had no choice (or problem!) in this, but it was certainly fitting. Unfortunately, my grandfather who meant a lot to me, passed away just over a week before I signed up. In his final days he moved from hospital into a hospice. I was aware of hospices before, but I experienced first-hand the excellent care he received benefiting both him and us as a family. It really is amazing to be able to offer a carefree environment and the simple things like really good food when these things matter most. 

This is just where some of your donation could go. Marie Curie will receive 100% of any donation you make!

Note: I will be undertaking this trip in March 2023, not August!


Marie Curie: Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. Marie Curie believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.
title: Everest Base Camp 2023 - Aston University

charity.description: Every day 250 people in the UK start losing their sight. With your help, we can be there when people need us most, support independent living, create an inclusive society and prevent avoidable sight loss. Every pound you raise will help create a future where sight loss is no longer a barrier.
charity.name: RNIB - Royal National Institute of Blind People
pageSummary: I am so honored to run because eye sight is so precious!
pageSummaryWhat: I am so honored to run
story:
Thanks for supporting my London Marathon challenge! I chose to apply for a slot on the RNIB team and am honored to be selected because our ability to see what's in front of us is taken for granted most everyday and sight loss effects so many people, old and young. I support RNIB because it is a strong resource for those battling sight loss and helping people adapt to the changes that happens with losing vision.

  Personally being born with a cataract and growing up with a weaker eye that had minimal sight, then going through different eye surgeries, (lens removal as an infant, strabismus surgery X2, lens implant surgery in 2019) more contacts and eye patches than I care to count and battling a whole lot of insecurity along the way; running for RNIB in this marathon gives this race a whole new purpose. I am excited to run and raise awareness for a charity that is supporting a mission that I hold dear to my heart. 

  Every day, 250 people in the UK start losing their sight. Too many still face isolation and depression, unable to achieve their potential in a world that blocks their way. RNIB wont stop until every last psychological and physical barrier has gone for good.With your help, RNIB can be there when people need them most, support independent living, create an inclusive society and prevent avoidable sight loss. Every pound you donate is helping create a future where sight loss is no longer a barrier.£20 could help someone feel more confident about living with sight loss, with personalised support from our expert Sight Loss Advice Service. £47 could help someone feel more positive about the future after losing their sight, through a one-to-one phone or online counselling session. £2,500 could make a new adult book available in our Talking Books library, enabling a person with sight loss to enjoy the latest best seller.
title: Mia's Run to support RNIB!

pageSummaryWhy: they've helped my Dad & I've got eye issues too.
story:
Thanks for your support with my London Marathon challenge!

Every day, 250 people in the UK start losing their sight. Too many still face isolation and depression, unable to achieve their potential in a world that blocks their way. RNIB wont stop until every last psychological and physical barrier has gone for good.

With your help, RNIB can be there when people need them most, support independent living, create an inclusive society and prevent avoidable sight loss. Every pound you donate is helping create a future where sight loss is no longer a barrier.

£20 could help someone feel more confident about living with sight loss, with personalised support from our expert Sight Loss Advice Service. £47 could help someone feel more positive about the future after losing their sight, through a one-to-one phone or online counselling session. £2,500 could make a new adult book available in our Talking Books library, enabling a person with sight loss to enjoy the latest best seller.

pageSummary: I am Running the London Marathon 2023 because of my Mum
pageSummaryWhat: I am Running the London Marathon 2023
story: Back in 2014 I ran my first  (and only) London Marathon raising money for The RNIB which has become a charity very close to me and my family. After being diagnosed with a horrible disease my Mum has been suffering with severe sight loss. It has completely changed her life and taken away her independence with things like not being able to drive , not being able to do things that everyone else takes for granted - not knowing if each day will be the last she sees her grandchildren, That's why I chose to run the London Marathon 8 years ago for my Mum and others like her and that's why I have chosen to run for them again.  Every day, 250 people in the UK start losing their sight. Too many still face isolation and depression, The RNIB provide help and equipment to help people those families living with  sight loss give them the chance to have a normal life.

charity.description: We are the UK's leading charity providing financial, social and emotional support to millions who have served and are currently serving in the British Armed Forces and their dependents.
charity.name: The Royal British Legion
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My name is Russ Stokes; I am a former Royal Engineer within the British Army. I will be completing 11 miles each day for the first 11 days of November, a total of 121 miles, raising funds that will help the Royal British Legion to continue its vital work.

I will be completing some walks in Dublin, incorporating a visit to The Irish National War Memorial Gardens and Grangegorman Military Cemetery. I will be in the Mourne Mountains and in the Glens of Antrim. Culminating on the 11th day in Belfast finishing at the War Memorial Belfast.

I will post updates each day as I take on my challenge and am looking to beat my target of £500.

Your donation could help provide emergency accommodation for a veteran in need, food vouchers for a family facing financial hardship, or training for Admiral nurses to provide specialist support and care for a veteran living with dementia.

eventName: Caerleon to Menin Gate Cycle Ride
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On Sunday 30th October I will be cycling 300 miles around the Caerleon one-way system to raise money for this year's Royal British Legion Poppy Appeal.

During July this year, a number of us cycled in Belgium where we visited the graves of three brave young men from Caerleon who paid the ultimate sacrifice in World War 1.

These men were Private Percy J Scannell, Private William H Wollan and Private Edgar Morgan.

As a mark of respect to all that did not return, I am going to cycle the distance between Caerleon and the Menin Gate Memorial, Ypres during 24 hours.

I'll be starting at 11am so please give me a shout and a wave.

Thanks in advance for your donations and support!

charity.description: We are the UK's leading charity providing financial, social and emotional support to millions who have served and are currently serving in the British Armed Forces and their dependents.
charity.name: The Royal British Legion
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

To pay tribute to those who have served and sacrificed, I will be climbing Nepal's Ama Dablam during Remembrance this year, along with a team of Armed Forces veterans. We will aim to summit the 6,812m peak on Remembrance Day, 11th November, and place a wreath at the top in honour of all those who have given their lives in conflict and to support the incredible work of the Royal British Legion. We'll mark the occasion with a two-minute silence.

The RBL's work provides financial, social and emotional support to members and veterans of the British Armed Forces and their families.

This will be a tough challenge for me, having only climbed Mont Blanc in the past (at 4,807m), and especially as Sir Edmund Hillary himself once described Ama Dablam as 'unclimbable'. Fortunately we'll have arguably the world's greatest mountaineer with us - Nims Purja, star of Netflix's '14 Peaks: Nothing Is Impossible' will be keeping us safe on the mountain.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Please give as generously as you can so that the Royal British Legion can continue supporting serving and ex-serving men and women and their families.

pageSummary: CACI are supporting Poppy Day because of those that lost their lives on active service.
pageSummaryWhy: of those that lost their lives on active service.
story:
The Poppy represents those who lost their lives on active service, from the beginning of the first world war right up to the present day.

It also honours the contribution of the civilian services and the uniformed services which contribute to national peace and security and acknowledges innocent civilians who have lost their lives in conflict and acts of terrorism.

The support that the Poppy Appeal provides is as vital as ever.  Every person, every donation and every poppy counts and only donations from the sale of red poppies goes directly towards helping the Armed Forces community.

CACI will match all donations raised.

Thank you.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our Thomson Reuters Poppy Appeal Just Giving page.

Most of you will be acquainted with the Royal British Legion's annual Poppy Appeal as part of the build up to Armistice Day and Remembrance Sunday,. Members of our armed forces (past and present) and supporters fundraising for this great cause are a familiar site on our daily commute. Following on from the last two year's successful virtual events to complement the in-person fundraising that happens, Thomson Reuters is launching its third Virtual Poppy appeal!

All funds raised will go directly to the Royal British Legion. The Royal British Legion is the UK's largest armed forces charity, providing lifelong support to serving and ex-serving personnel and their families. In times like this, the support and services they offer are a vital lifeline to many, and more important than ever. Thank you in advance for your support of this important cause.
title: Thomson Reuters Poppy Appeal 2022

story:
The RBL is at the heart of a national network that supports the Armed Forces community. Established in 1921, RBL is the largest Armed Forces charity, with 180,000 members, 110,000 volunteers and a network of partners and charities; helping provide lifelong support to serving and ex-serving personnel and their families.

Your donations will be matched too. If you'd like to make a donation via CAF cheque, please email crmatters@schroders.com to share the amount with us to be matched.

charity.name: The Royal British Legion
story:
Hello! We are raising money for the Royal British Legion this year. Enter our raffle to win this beautiful copper poppy bundle. This includes x5 pocket poppies plus wall bracket to display as per the picture attached. Supporting our raffle supports the poppy appeal and our armed forces.

To enter correctly simply donate £5 for a ticket.

£10 for 2 tickets, £15 for 3 tickets, £20 for 4 tickets and so on. Attach your name to your donation so we can see and add your name to a ticket/s.

The raffle will be drawn on Friday 11th November @7PM.

Best of luck!
title: Copper Hearts' Raffle

charity.description: We are the UK's leading charity providing financial, social and emotional support to millions who have served and are currently serving in the British Armed Forces and their dependents.
charity.name: The Royal British Legion
story:
Hello dear friends

It’s Remembrance Sunday on 13th November and time to raise funds for the Royal British Legion (RBL). As last year, I will be running two 5k.’s (3.1 miles) at Market Rasen Racecourse on 5th and Cleethorpes Country Park on 12th November. PARKRUN are having major city events but there is nothing local, so these are my ‘Poppy Runs’ in support of RBL’s 2022 appeal.

I know you may have already bought your Poppy or perhaps supported RBL in other ways this year. I know times are hard, but I am requesting you dig deep and support me once more.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Or you can hand me your donation and I will put it in for you.
title: Graham's My Poppy Run 2022

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I am taking part in a a 14 Km guided RUN, stopping at several war memorials to pay respect and share a moment of reflection. This is my biggest challenge yet and I'm not promising to run it all. And I originally wasn't going to fundraise but it's for a great cause so anything you can spare is appreciated for this amazing cause. I have paid my entry to this event and all profits from that go to the charity! Thanks in advance!

We start at Birkenshaw Church with a short ceremony, march up to East Brierley church lay a wreath and then run over to Birkenshaw Roundabout, then on to Cleckheaton Memorial, Heckmondwike Memorial then finish with a run on to Batley Memorial.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: The Royal British Legion
pageSummary: I am running the Great North Run to raise money because We might not know them all, but we owe them all
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Great North Run to raise money
pageSummaryWhy: We might not know them all, but we owe them all
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

5km Poppy Run ✅

Climb Scaffel Pike ✅

Now it’s time for my next challenge to raise money for the RBL.

 I've decided to dig the running shoes out again and take part in the Great North Run 2023. By taking part in this challenge I'll be raising more funds to support the Royal British Legion. The Legion was founded to help those in need following a national crisis. Right now they are helping those who are isolated from family, facing homelessness, struggling to feed their children and are in financial crisis. They are working tirelessly to ensure that those who have served are being looked after no matter what challenges they, and the country faces. Your donation will mean they can continue to provide the life-changing support that our Armed Forces community needs and deserves. Thank You.

To those in uniform serving today and to those who have served in the past, I honor you today and every day.

story: 30th Signal regiment intend on raising money for the Royal British Legion to help injured servicemen and women. The aim of the event is to push a Land Rover 90 (TUL) for 24hrs as a team. To get more support from the public and raising personnel standards within the unit, we intend on utilising the internationally recognised accolade of Guinness world record holders.

charity.description: We're a Christian aid and development agency, following Jesus to the places of greatest need to respond to disasters and help communities unlock their own potential to overcome poverty. We won't stop until poverty stops.
charity.name: Tearfund
pageSummary: Dare to Journey because we believe in God's heart for those in need.
pageSummaryWhy: we believe in God's heart for those in need.
story:
Join us as we dare to journey, walking the same distance a refugee would have to travel to escape conflict. Through this challenge, we will be helping to raise awareness and advocate for their rights. At least 89.3 million people worldwide have been forced to flee their homes.

We have chosen to travel the route of Kabul to the border of Pakistan, walking a total distance of 115 miles between us. We will be doing this throughout November! 

If you choose to donate you can also send a dare for Josh and I to complete whilst on our travels!

Why don't you Dare to Journey with us today and give to this campaign? How can you be generous with what's in your hands?
title: Nicola & Josh's Dare to Journey Challenge

story:
The Big Quiz Night is a nationwide, multi-venue quiz. In November 2022 hundreds of churches and thousands of people will come together in communities across the country for a night of quizzing fun, raising money to help end extreme poverty.


Come and join us in Widford Parish to take part:

Friday 19th November, 7:30pm at the Church of the Holy Spirit, Forest Drive

charity.description: We're a Christian aid and development agency, following Jesus to the places of greatest need to respond to disasters and help communities unlock their own potential to overcome poverty. We won't stop until poverty stops.
charity.name: Tearfund
pageSummary: We're participating in the Tearfund Big Quiz Night
pageSummaryWhat: We're participating in the Tearfund Big Quiz Night
story:
The money you raise will transform the lives of people like Zuleima. 

Zuleima is a 35-year-old mother of three from Venezuela. It is a country struggling beneath the weight of a massive economic crisis. 

Along with more than a million other Venezuelans, Zuleima made the decision to flee to neighbouring Colombia. [I was] leaving my house, my home, my memories, Zuleima says, It was very difficult to leave it all behind.

The church opened their doors, and they helped me, says Zuleima. Not only giving me food and a place to live, but also taking care of my emotions, giving me words of hope, giving me words of faith.

As well as providing support for refugees immediate needs, Tearfunds local church partners have been setting up support groups that help people like Zuleima find new income opportunities. 

A gift of £24 could provide two women like Zuliema with the training and tools they need to provide a better future for their families

story:
We are holding a Big Quiz on Saturday 19th November 6pm - 9pm, starting with a hot meal.  

Please donate £5 per person here, then register your attendance by clicking Register or Log In at the top of our website https://www.stjamesclitheroe.co.uk/

Either form your own team of 6 beforehand, or just turn up and we will put you in a team.

The money you raise will transform the lives of people like Zuleima. Zuleima is a 35-year-old mother of three from Venezuela. charity.description: We're a Christian aid and development agency, following Jesus to the places of greatest need to respond to disasters and help communities unlock their own potential to overcome poverty. We won't stop until poverty stops.
charity.name: Tearfund
pageSummary: We are doing the Big Quiz Night on 19th November because they do a great job alleviating poverty.
pageSummaryWhat: We are doing the Big Quiz Night on 19th November
pageSummaryWhy: they do a great job alleviating poverty.
story:
The money you raise will transform the lives of people like Zuleima. 

Zuleima is a 35-year-old mother of three from Venezuela. It is a country struggling beneath the weight of a massive economic crisis. 

Along with more than a million other Venezuelans, Zuleima made the decision to flee to neighbouring Colombia. [I was] leaving my house, my home, my memories, Zuleima says, It was very difficult to leave it all behind.

The church opened their doors, and they helped me, says Zuleima. Not only giving me food and a place to live, but also taking care of my emotions, giving me words of hope, giving me words of faith.

As well as providing support for refugees immediate needs, Tearfunds local church partners have been setting up support groups that help people like Zuleima find new income opportunities. 

A gift of £24 could provide two women like Zuliema with the training and tools they need to provide a better future for their families
title: Immanuel Church in Southbourne is fundraising for the Big Quiz Night

charity.description: World Vision believes that by working together with children, their communities, and our supporters and partners, the lives of the world’s most vulnerable children can be transformed. As a Christian organisation, we aspire to reflect God’s unconditional love in all we do.
charity.name: World Vision UK
eventName: World Vision Ullswater way challenge walk
pageSummary: I am taking part in the Ullswater Challenge walk because of World Vision's life changing work in our world
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in the Ullswater Challenge walk
pageSummaryWhy: of World Vision's life changing work in our world
story:
6K is the average distance that children often girls walk every single day to fetch water for their community. This water may still be dirty, but they have no choice.  The Ullswater challenge walk is 21 miles and others in our team of 15 will do this!  I am battling with sciatica, but I'm going to do what I can manage and aiming to complete at least 6 miles. The money raised will fund World Vision's water and sanitation projects across the world. 

On a personal note, I am a World Vision staff employee. I have the privilege of reporting the impact of our work (as my job!) and I am just as proud of the work we do round the world in humanitarian emergencies and places of chronic child well-being need, as I was when I joined in 2004. 

Last year World Vision UK funded work reached over 2 million children across 34 countries, benefitting more than 4 million people in total. We responded to humanitarian emergencies in 18 countries, reaching over 1.7 million people – over half of them children. 

Impact Report | World Vision UK

Thank you for your help!

charity.description: Comic Relief is a UK charity which aims to create a just world, free from poverty. Since 1985, Comic Relief has raised over £1 billion. That money has helped, and is helping, people living incredibly tough lives, both at home in the UK and across the world.
charity.name: Comic Relief
story: Red Nose Day is back on Friday 17 March and we're joining schools up and down the nation to show that laughter has the power to change lives. However much you can spare, your donation will make a difference to people here in the UK and around the world. Don't forget to tick the Gift Aid option, if you can, so Comic Relief can claim an extra 25% from the government. From us and everyone at Comic Relief, thank you. You're wonderful.

charity.description:
Dogs Trust is the largest dog welfare charity in the UK. We rescue and rehome dogs all over the UK (Ireland too). We never put a healthy dog down. We also promote responsible dog ownership through youth education, neutering and microchipping campaigns. 
A dog is for Life, not just for Christmas ©
charity.name: Dogs Trust
story: As a bunch of dog owners and dog lovers, we thought who better to choose as our charity of the year. This October the team is fundraising to support The Dogs Trust by walking/running/swimming the distance by road from John O'Groats to Lands End. That's 874 miles in total...!!! We will clock up the miles throughout the month, finishing with groups of regional team walks on 28th October Please support us by donating as much as you can, and help us to support the amazing work of The Dogs Trust

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description:
ActionAid is an international humanitarian charity that works with women and girls living in poverty.

Our dedicated local staff are changing the world with women and girls. We are ending violence and fighting poverty so that all women, everywhere, can create the future they want.
charity.name: ActionAid
pageSummary: I am raising money for ActionAid because To help put a stop to violence against women
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money for ActionAid
pageSummaryWhy: To help put a stop to violence against women
story: This November, I am taking part in The 137 Challenge with ActionAid. Did you know, one in three women will experience some form of violence in their lifetime, and 137 women are killed per day by a partner or family member? Donating just £23 could pay a counsellors salary for a month meaning women and girls who have survived violence have access to crucial psychosocial support to help them recover. ActionAid is an international charity that works with women and girls living in poverty. Their dedicated local staff are changing the world with women and girls. They are ending violence and fighting poverty so that all women, everywhere can create the future they want. If you'd like to find out more about the amazing work ActionAid does, please visit their website at www.actionaid.org.uk.

pageSummary: The Happiness Anonymous Share Show is back! because We can all do something for Ukraine
pageSummaryWhat: The Happiness Anonymous Share Show is back!
pageSummaryWhy: We can all do something for Ukraine
story: The Happiness Anonymous Share Show is back! And this time it’s fuelled by bonfires, fireworks, guys Fawks and the spooky season. We are fundraising to support the DEC Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal. Heavy fighting, shelling and air strikes across Ukraine have had devastating consequences. Already, over two million people have fled their homes to escape intense conflict in Ukraine. Leaving behind loved ones, livelihoods and almost everything they own, they need shelter, food, and water. People are losing their homes and lives, essential services like water and healthcare have been hit and temperatures have dropped below zero. Please support my fundraiser to help reach those in urgent need in Ukraine and neighbouring countries. With your help we can support ActionAid and the DEC in scaling up their response and help families to stay warm and protect women and girls. - £10 could provide essential hygiene supplies for 1person for one month - £50 could provide blankets for 4 families to keep them warm - £100 could provide emergency food for 2 families for one month

pageSummary: 137 squats a day in Nov. /13.7km run/137mins bike because 137 women a day are killed by partner or family
pageSummaryWhat: 137 squats a day in Nov. /13.7km run/137mins bike
pageSummaryWhy: 137 women a day are killed by partner or family
story:
This November, I am taking part in The 137 Challenge with ActionAid. Did you know, one in three women will experience some form of violence in their lifetime, and 137 women are killed per day by a partner or family member? Donating just £23 could pay a counsellors salary for a month meaning women and girls who have survived violence have access to crucial psychosocial support to help them recover. ActionAid is an international charity that works with women and girls living in poverty. Their dedicated local staff are changing the world with women and girls. They are ending violence and fighting poverty so that all women, everywhere can create the future they want. If you'd like to find out more about the amazing work ActionAid does, please visit their website at www.actionaid.org.uk.

I'm doing "137"every day in November. It's 137 squats per day, but to mix it up and make it harder some days I'll switch this out for 137 minutes of cycling, or 13.7km running, or 137 bounces on a trampoline... or whatever anyone else can think of, using the number 137. Get creative and suggest something?

I've connected to Strava, so you'll see evidence of some sort that I'm doing it. I'm not videoing myself squatting (nobody wants to see that).

story:
Recovery is taff and unbearable for the victim and their family/friends around them, so getting the right professional support is super important. Unfortunately, a lot of people are unable to excess the right support for financial reasons.

The work this charity is doing is truly remarkable. “If you support me by donating, your money will, for example, pay a counsellor's salary, meaning women and girls who have survived violence have access to crucial psychosocial support to help them recover. 

Those who know me know that this subject is very dear to my family and me, so from the bottom of my heart:  “Thank you for your support.”

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Guide Dogs wouldn't be here without you. Our life-changing services depend on donations. In the UK, one more person loses their sight every six minutes. 

The money you raise will help us train up more puppies, and transform the life of someone with sight loss. We've set you a fundraising target of just £125. That's enough to give a new guide dog owner a Starter Kit to help their life with a guide dog.

pageSummary: Sarah and I are doing a 5km walk because they do some incredible work helping others
pageSummaryWhat: Sarah and I are doing a 5km walk
pageSummaryWhy: they do some incredible work helping others
story:
Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

Sarah and I are joining in with the walk to try and raise some money to help out. Covid impacted not only their ability to fundraise, but also find volunteers to carry out the vital training in the early stages. We are hoping to help raise some money to return this to the levels it was at before, maybe even further.

pageSummary: Raising money to help train a puppy because the charity meant so much to David Edwards
pageSummaryWhat: Raising money to help train a puppy
pageSummaryWhy: the charity meant so much to David Edwards
story:
David Edwards (July 13, 1951 - October 15, 2022) was a proud Scotsman, husband, father, grandfather and friend to many who started to lose his sight over 30 years ago. He was also a runner...

Despite his disability David was a veteran of over 200 parkruns and competed in events such as The Virtual London Marathon and Great South Run with his guides, John Baker and Cliffe Tribe.

He was an avid campaigner for the Guide Dogs Charity and will be remembered for his loyalty, spirit, generosity and courage. 

The challenge on November 20, 2022 at the Wimborne 10, a ten mile road race, will involve Cliffe being fully blindfolded and guided by John in tribute and in memory to a great friend and running companion.
title: David's Guide - A 10 mile blindfold run in memory of a friend

pageSummary: I am going to cycle round GEC park 50 times! because My Grandad needed Spencer his Guide dog!
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to cycle round GEC park 50 times!
pageSummaryWhy: My Grandad needed Spencer his Guide dog!
story:
My Grandad David, lost lots of his sight, and needed Spencer his Guide Dog to help him do lots of things! The Guide Dogs were very important to my Grandad. 

My Grandad sadly died, and I would like to cycle 50 laps to remember him! 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Together, we'll raise £5,000 to name a UK guide dog.

WHY HOPE?

2022 has been my most challenging year for so many reasons. Guide Dogs has given me more than 23 years o independence and freedom. My WHY is purely to say thank you. I've been proud to volunteer with the charity since 1998, but here, for the first time without a guide dog since 2 August 1999 and having had the worst year of my life - hands down, I realised, in a cab on my way home that life is what you make it. I questioned what has been absent for me in 2022 and the answer is clearly one word - HOPE.

Over the years, I've done some pretty daft things to raise money for the charity I owe so much to from bearing the physical scars of breaking my hip in 2008 running the London Marathon (you can read about that at just giving.com/themarathanmen ) to blind walking 90 miles for Guide Dogs with Siobhan to name Guide Dog Pup Dilley and even to get together with my mate Dave to name a guide dog Pup Finn, who's working with his owner in Leeds as we speak, I've always had the gratitude and crucially the confidence to put my hand up and say, we can do this.

2022 has isolated and to a great extent, trapped me as I am now a full time cane user until the right match com3s up with the right dog, at the right time for me. I've been told that match is likely to take two years due to the very specific matching requirements - but in the UK, there were around 5,000 guide dogs before the pandemic... now due to a mix of Guide Dogs stopping their breading programme for social distancing and safety reasons to not being able to socialise dogs in realistic situations, there are fewer than 4,000. If you think about that, 1 in 5 people who had a guide dog before the pandemic now does not.

It would mean the world to me if you could help me and work with me to name a guide dog pup HOPE before Christmas. Any amount of pennies you feel you can chuck in would be gratefully received and 100% of it will go to HOPE of 2022.

On a personal note, I need to regain the confidence this year has robbed from me. I'm prepared to do some pretty stupid things to hit the target. If you don't want to see me doing stupid things like the 90 mile walk through dangerous conditions, dig deep :)

Also, if we haven't spoken in a while, why not say hello. You'd be surprised the good that could do.

Ok so thank you everyone. Keep it here for updates and expect lots of different fundraising ideas to emerge until we hit the target. How quickly can we do it? Thank you all SO much.

==============

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. 

Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

charity.name: Islamic Relief
story:
Salaam everyone! I hope you all are well. As part of charity week, I am planning to walk 10,000 steps a day to raise money for orphans and vulnerable children.

As somebody who is passionate about social mobility, I found this cause extremely important to my heart. Every child deserves the best start in life and the right support and resources to do so. As Muslims, we have a duty to care for the poor and vulnerable (and that includes children). As Allah (swt) says in the Quran:

'Be good to orphans and the needy. Speak nicely to people. And help the poor' [Surah Baqarah, ayah 83]

Furthermore, in Islam, orphans are respected and honoured like ordinary children. There is immense respect for the Muslim who takes care of orphans. The Prophet Muhammad (saw) said:

''I and the person who looks after an orphan and provides for him, will be in Paradise like this," putting his index and middle fingers together. [Sahih al-Bukhari, 6005]

If you can donate even a pound, it can go a long way to help transform children's lives ❤️

Jazakallah for your donation and may Allah (swt) reward you all. If you cannot donate, please share so more people can potentially help.

story:
On the 29th October, we will be taking on the 30km Amersham Loop challenge to fundraise for Imperial College Charity Week 2022, Insha'Allah.

We will be fundraising for sustainable causes including, but not limited to, the following:

- Flooding in Bangladesh and Pakistan
- Hunger appeal in Kenya and Somalia
- Education for Rohingya refugees
- Healthcare access in Afghanistan

Please donate generously to help those less fortunate than ourselves.

- Yasin and Abdurrahman

charity.name: Islamic Relief
story:
Asalaamualaykum. I am raising money for orphans and children in need.

This is part of Edge Hill's Islamic Society collaboration with Islamic Relief as part of Charity Week this year.

Please do donate and spread the word!

Abu Huraira reported: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him, said): “Charity does not decrease wealth, no one forgives another but that Allah increases his honor, and no one humbles himself for the sake of Allah but that Allah raises his status.”

100% of the money raised will be going to support 18 projects Insha'Allah. With a focus on Education, Hunger & Malnutrition and Emergency causes. Helping people in Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Malaysia, Mali, Myanmar, Niger, Pakistan, Palestine, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Syria & Zanzibar.

Jazakallahu khayran for your support❤️
- Sadiya

story:
السلام عليكم

مَّن ذَا ٱلَّذِى يُقْرِضُ ٱللَّهَ قَرْضًا حَسَنًۭا فَيُضَـٰعِفَهُۥ لَهُۥٓ أَضْعَافًۭا كَثِيرَةًۭ ۚ وَٱللَّهُ يَقْبِضُ وَيَبْصُۜطُ وَإِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ - “Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times over? And it is Allah who withholds and grants abundance, and to Him you will be returned” (Qur’an, 2: 245).

I will be hiking at Snowdon this year to help support the most needy. Please donate generously, knowing the more we give sadaqah the more we increase our iman.

charity.name: Islamic Relief
story:
Umar is looking to raise as much as possible to go towards the causes of Education, Hunger & Malnutrition and Emergency Relief.

These 3 categories are split across many countries, ranging from Pakistan and Bangladesh to Zanzibar, Malaysia, Somalia, Palestine, Kenya, Ethiopia and many more!

Please help us raise the money as part of this year's Charity Week, in return I have committed ourselves to do the following challenges for every donation target we hit!

Challenge (£500) - Ice bucket challenge (on campus) 🧊🪣🥶

Challenge (£1000) - Gross Smoothie 🤮🥤🤢

Challenge (£2000) - 24 Hours in VR 😵‍💫👨‍💻🥽

And the big one...

Challenge (£3000) - DYEING MY HAIR!!! 🟣? 🟢? 🟡?

charity.description: Islamic Relief is an international relief and development charity that aims to alleviate the suffering of the world's poorest people. As well as responding to disasters and emergencies, it promotes sustainable economic and social development by working with local communities - regardless of race, religion or gender.
charity.name: Islamic Relief
story:
Charity Week has ARRIVED! And to challenge myself this #CW2022, I've decided to 'Step' it up (how could I not?) and aim to complete the 10K Step Challenge! I am committing to a minimum of 10000 steps a day for 7 days this Charity Week- my legs are already aching at the thought of it (and the rainy forecast won't stop me!)

This week, I am joined by thousands of volunteers taking part in Charity Week in all sorts of ways, across 8 countries (in 282 cities!), working together to save lives. This project is so special to me and so many of us- and it's making a real difference.

Please help me make a difference to the lives of orphans and children in need by making a donation, to support these BEAUTIFUL causes: https://charityweek.com/projects/

Zakat can be donated too: just type "Zakat" in the comment with your donation so we can ensure it is allocated appropriately!

Please spread the word by sharing this page with your friends and family. May you be rewarded abundantly!

#CW2022 #UnitedWeWin

story:
Assalamu alaykum everyone,

Imaad and Mithal are looking to raise as much money as we can to donate to projects such as Education, Hunger & Malnutrition and Emergencies. These 3 categories are split across many countries, ranging from Pakistan and Bangladesh to Zanzibar, Malaysia, Somalia, Palestine, Kenya, Ethiopia and many more! Please help us raise the money as part of this year's Charity Week!

For every £1 donated we will do 5 PUSH UPS 💪🏽

We will record videos of ourselves and post our progress throughout Charity Week 📷

"The strong believer is more beloved to Allah than the weak believer, but there is goodness in both of them." - Sahih Muslim 2664

May Allah grant us all strength and success. Ameen 🙏🏽

story:
I am fundraising to help save children's lives in countries across the globe!
- Funding sponsorships of orphans from across multiple countries that include South Africa, Sudan, Pakistan and Gaza.
- Providing quality healthcare facilities/support to orphans and vulnerable children in Gaza, Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Turkey and Chechnya.
- Building schools and providing disadvantaged children access to education and training in Kenya, Syria, Kosovo, Pakistan, Mali & South Africa.

story:
Salaam everyone.

I am fundraising to help save orphans, young children and families’ lives in disadvantaged countries across the globe. Let’s get ready to raise money for our brothers and sisters That need your help around the world!

Please donate whatever you can, or even share around you're socials for this beautiful cause and of course for the endless rewards (Sadaqah Jaariyah) Insha’Allah.
May Allah bless, increase you in wealth and elevate you in the highest levels of Jannah. Ameen:)

- Prophet Muhammad (SAW), said “The believer’s shade on the Day of Judgement will be his charity.” (Al-Tirmidhi)

charity.description: Age UK is the national charity dedicated to helping everyone make the most of later life. Ageing is not an illness, but it can be challenging. We help more than 7 million people every year, providing companionship, advice and support for older people who need it most.
charity.name: Age UK
story: Most people will feel lonely at some point in their lives. It’s a deeply personal experience that - in most cases - will thankfully pass. Sadly, 2.65m older people feel they have no one to turn to for help and around 3.9m older people consider TV to be their main form of company. Donating to this page will help the national Age UK to continue providing vital services that offer companionship, advice and support for older people facing later life alone.

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
pageSummary: Emily Vincent is raising funds because time is running out to save the planet!
pageSummaryWhy: time is running out to save the planet!
story:
On Saturday 29th October- I will be asking the rugby supporters going to the Quins/London Irish game at the Stoop for donations in return for a rugby themed cake.

Just in case you are not attending- but might want to help me reach my target- I thought I would set up this page. I will give you a cake next time I see you! 

Why am I supporting WWF?

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk
title: Baking cakes to combat climate change
image.caption: NA
media.images.image.caption: NA
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
This winter I'll be taking part in Brave the Chill in aid of WWF. Sponsor me to help WWF bring our world back to life.

Climate change poses the biggest threat to the future of our planet. Global temperatures have been rising for over a century and are now the highest on record. One landscape the climate crisis has put into meltdown is the Arctic, with this polar region warming almost three times faster than the global average. It may seem a bit chilly for some of us, but the Arctic is crucial for lots of reasons.

Polar bears and walrus call this freezing landscape their home. But their environment is changing, because of global warming. The sea ice during the summer months is declining, and with global warming, that ice is shrinking fast.

By sponsoring me to Brave the Chill, together we can help bring our world back to life.

story: This winter I'll be taking part in Brave the Chill in aid of WWF. Sponsor me to help WWF bring our world back to life. Climate change poses the biggest threat to the future of our planet. Global temperatures have been rising for over a century and are now the highest on record. This causes negative impacts such as the melting of Arctic sea-ice, prolonged heat-waves and rising sea-levels, but we can do something about it. By sponsoring me to Brave the Chill, together we can help WWF continue to reduce our impact on the climate, and ease the pressures on the world's most vulnerable places, people and wildlife to bring our world back to life.

charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
This winter I'll be taking part in Brave the Chill in aid of WWF. Sponsor me to help WWF bring our world back to life.

Climate change poses the biggest threat to the future of our planet. Global temperatures have been rising for over a century and are now the highest on record. One landscape the climate crisis has put into meltdown is the Arctic, with this polar region warming almost three times faster than the global average. It may seem a bit chilly for some of us, but the Arctic is crucial for lots of reasons.

Polar bears and walrus call this freezing landscape their home. But their environment is changing, because of global warming. The sea ice during the summer months is declining, and with global warming, that ice is shrinking fast.

By sponsoring me to Brave the Chill, together we can help bring our world back to life.

Global temperatures have been rising for over a century and are now the highest on record. This causes negative impacts such as the melting of Arctic sea-ice, prolonged heat-waves and rising sea-levels, but we can do something about it. By sponsoring me to Brave the Chill, together we can help WWF continue to reduce our impact on the climate, and ease the pressures on the world's most vulnerable places, people and wildlife to bring our world back to life.

eventName: Reading Half Marathon & Three Peaks Challenge
story:
As you may know, I am an avid supporter of the World Wildlife Fund and the work it does to protect our amazing planet. Climate change has left our world in crisis; from the destruction of kelp forests which absorb more carbon than any other flora, to the humble bee which ensures our continued existence on Planet Earth.

Hence, I am doing what I can to protect the future of OUR planet for today and for future generations by raising money for the WWF by running the Reading Half Marathon and subsequently taking on the Three Peaks Challenge in June 2023.

Many of you are aware I am studying for a degree in Zoology in order for me to do 'my bit' for our planet.  This is also going to be a personal struggle for me taking into consideration the spinal fusion I had last spine last year.  It will be no mean feat, but this charity is one I feel strongly about.

Please give whatever you can afford, no matter how small, it will go a long way....

Thank you for reading.

Jess

title: kieron's Barnardos London marathon
image.caption: NA
media.images.image.caption: NA
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description: Barnardo’s is the UK’s largest national children’s charity. In 2019-20, we supported work with 358,800 children, young people, parents and carers, across more than 800 services and partnerships throughout the UK.
charity.name: Barnardo's
pageSummary: I am running the London Marathon because children deserve to have a happy & safe childhood
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the London Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: children deserve to have a happy & safe childhood
story:
My running journey started back in November ‘20 when I
signed up to my first half marathon… We were in and out of lockdowns, I was in
and out of furlough and as if that wasn’t bad enough, I was turning 40. I was
sick of not looking after myself; mentally and physically – I was overweight, I
drank too much, and my anxiety was at an all-time high.

Nearly 2 years on, 2 half marathons under my belt, a few
10ks, joining 2 running clubs, I’ve met so many new people who are so positive,
inspiring and I’ve learned so much. I am off anti-depressants which I started
in my early 20’s, I’m fitter than I’ve ever been and my outlook on life is very
different. So much so, here’s the next challenge…London 23rd April 2023…26.2
miles.

Whoever you speak to that has done this event will tell you
it’s the most amazing experience …but it’s also a bit brutal. Not just on the
day when that wall you are likely to slam into has the strength to literally
take you off your feet, the lost toenails, the chaffing, the dodgy stomachs after
endless energy gels (I’m not really selling this, am I?). But the 20 (ish)
weeks that it takes to get you into a position where you are ready physically
and mentally. At this time of year that means cold mornings, dark nights,
horizontal rain, wind, sleet and who knows maybe a bit of snow? This is why I
always said my first (and possibly only) marathon, not only had to be London,
but also, for charity as its people believing in you, cheering you on and
donating to your cause that gets you out of bed and out that door.

I am running for #teambarnardos, who I am so honoured to
work for. As fulfilling as working for a charity is, it’s also heart-breaking
to hear some of the stories behind the children, young people, parents, and
carers across the UK who we support. The issues that we face are very different
from when the charity was first established, but the message remains the same: that
all children and young people deserve the right to a happy and safe childhood.

Barnardo’s work in championing social reforms for children
is as relevant now as it was back in the mid-1800’s. The stories of
trafficking, sexual abuse, violence, mental health and online safety are signs
of the times and access to vital services, and giving these vulnerable members
of our society a voice where it matters couldn’t be provided if it wasn’t for
your donations to this fabulous charity.

If you’d like to read more about the work that we do, please
go to www.barnardos.org.uk.

Thank you for taking the time to read my story…now please
click that donate button and I’ll get my trainers on…this is for you and the
kids 🏃🏻‍♀️🏃🏻‍♀️.

Nicole x

charity.name: BBC Children in Need
story:
Children in Need is happening so we would like you all to get involved!!

You can wear spotty clothes and/or pyjamas on Tuesday 15th and Thursday 17th November (Suggested donation £1)

There will also be a BAKE OFF on Tuesday 15th November.

Entries will cost 50p and then all cakes will be available to buy for donations to Children in Need. 
Cakes can be dropped off to the Hub Office between 8.45-9.30am on Monday or Tuesday.  Judging will then commence and cakes can be bought from 12.15pm.

Thank you all in advance for your wonderful support

The lasting effects of the Covid-19 crisis on the lives of children and young people are extensive, but BBC Children in Need is here to make sure that no child is left behind. Currently funding over 2,500 local charities and projects across the UK, BBC Children in Need supports children and young people to thrive and be the best they can be.Join in and together, we can change young lives.

pageSummary: Step up pop pickers because it's the one, the only.... Lyric Quiz!
pageSummaryWhy: it's the one, the only.... Lyric Quiz!
story:
100 UK Top 40 lyric snippets. But what's the song & who was that artist?!

Request a question sheet, return your answers, or ask questions via CiNLyricQuizATgmail.com.

Please donate £1 min. per player
even if they don't get any of the answers, cos charidee...

No limit on team size - the more the merrier.
Full rules are on the question sheet.

Deadline for submissions: Midnight, Friday 18th Nov 2022 (the night of the big telly event)

Can we top last year's fabulous total of £646?

Ways to donate:

  • If you can, please use JustGiving, so we can all see how much the quiz has raised this year.
    Alternatively:
  • Drop us the cash in person and we'll add it here for you*
    or
  • Donate direct to Children in Need via the method of your choice.

Thank you so much for playing the Children in Need Lyric Quiz 2022, and for donating your hard-earned to this great cause.

* Contact: CiNLyricQuizATgmail.com

eventName: babyballet Dancing in Pyjamas for Children in Need
pageSummary: We are dancing in pyjamas because every child deserves to be safe and happy.
pageSummaryWhy: every child deserves to be safe and happy.
story:
Every year our babyballet® stars across the UK absolutely love attending their classes in their pyjamas, in the week leading up to BBCs Children In Need.

We dance, skip, hop and sing at class, all while wearing pyjamas and we ask our wonderful babyballet® grown ups to donate what they can.

We will be inviting our babyballet stars to wear their pyjamas in class from 12th November - 18th November 2022. We cannot wait to see how much fun we have dancing in our pyjamas this year and hope to raise lots of money for a great cause.

eventName: Guess the name of the panda
pageSummary: Please guess the name of the Panada for £1 a go. because Children need help.
pageSummaryWhat: Please guess the name of the Panada for £1 a go.
story:
Pippa would like to raise some money for children in need by running a guess the name of the panda competition. She has been inspired to run this competition by Blue Peter as she wants to earn her blue Peter silver badge, which is gained by doing an act of kindness or fundraising. 

Please select £1 donation and message your chosen name. 

The winning name will be picked at random out of a hat and will be announced on Monday, 1st November. The winner will receive the bear!
title: Pippa'a Guess the name of the panda

pageSummary: Movathon- 10minutes to run/ dance / skip move
pageSummaryWhat: Movathon- 10minutes to run/ dance / skip move
story:
Supercharge your fundraising by doing something you love, then making it longer, faster or bigger than ever before.Its important to us that everyone can take part so that every girl and young woman has a chance to do amazing things, whoever they are and wherever theyre from.Whether its a group of girls from your unit trying their favourite styles of dance, team football drill races, a walking or running relay, reading competition or doing a community clean-up, wed love to see it!This is how you can get involved:Choose an activity youll love doing. Think how you can supercharge it by getting together with friends or girls in your unit to make it longer, faster or bigger than ever before.Set

4th Alresford Brownies will be running a movathon- run, jug, dance or skip for 10 minutes a day, every day from Friday 11.nov- Fri 18 nov. This will be done in the meeting on Wednesday 16th

We will also be decorating and selling some pudsey biscuits during the meeting
title: 4th Alresford Brownies movathon

charity.name: BBC Children in Need
story:
We are doing what we love, with a fundraising twist for BBC Children in Need. Together we can support children and young people across the UK to rebuild their lives.

Parklands Halloween House is a labour of love. We love to see the joy and anticipation it brings to the community. Every year we have tried to do it bigger and better than the previous year and this year we have some singing competition with a couple of cheeky skeletons! Since 2015 Parklands Halloween House has committed every donation to Children In Need with a running total thus far of £7067.23. We are very proud that every donation from our visitors goes to BBC Children In Need and benefits Children in Northern Ireland. To make donating even easier, you can donate via Just Giving and our Facebook page. Thank you all for your support to BBC CHILDREN IN NEED and thank you for coming to visit
title: Parklands Halloween House

pageSummary: Porsche Aberdeen are walking 885km because Peter Vardy's dedication to One Child Programme.
pageSummaryWhy: Peter Vardy's dedication to One Child Programme.
story:
Between the 1st of November to the 18th - Elaine, Paul, Di, Andy, Craig, Shelagh, Yvonne, Nicole, Tom, Dave, Gav, Peter, Rhiannon and Nyall will be challenging ourselves to walk 885km which is the equivalent distance from Aberdeen to London. We are hoping to smash this target and raise as much as we can for this charity. 

Since 2017, the Peter Vardy Foundation was created as a way of distributing 10% of all profits from Peter Vardy Limited to good causes to improve the lives of vulnerable children and young people both locally and internationally. 

You can find all the details of numerous charities that the Peter Vardy group supports here; 

https://www.petervardy.com/peter-vardy-foundation/about-us
title: Porsche Centre Aberdeen's Sponsored Walk

charity.name: BBC Children in Need
story:
Joe Wicks will be leading the drive to get people across the UK walking, talking and reconnecting. We would love you to get involved too, by heading to your local parkrun and walking the route with friends and family in your best fancy dress. In return, were asking you to donate what you can, if you can, to BBC Children in Need, so were able to help children and young people who will be hit hardest by the cost of living crisis and who are struggling with their mental health.

To find out where Joe will be walking and for more information about Walk with Joe, click here. (https://www.bbcchildreninneed.co.uk/fundraising/walk-with-joe/)

Thank you for your support, your donation will make a massive difference.
title: Girl Guiding Ash District take on ParkRun!

eventName: Ingo & Senen's Big Walk To Nailsworth
story:
Senen has convinced her brother Ingo to walk the estimated 12 miles across country from Wotton to Nailsworth to raise some money for Children in Need. As Ingo is a bit of a 'reluctant walker' we're not quite sure how she has achieved this but he has signed up to the mission. 

As their dad Roger will be navigating this route for the first time, this walk may actually be even longer than we anticipate (but don't tell Ingo). 

We would hugely appreciate ANY support, esp considering how tight finances are at the moment. A couple of pounds will make the kid's day and obviously go to a great cause!
title: heidi's Ingo & Senen's Big Walk To Nailsworth

charity.name: BBC Children in Need
pageSummary: Supporting BBC Children in Need because Every Child Matters
story:
In order to support young children across the United Kingdom we at every MPCT LCG Military academy across the United Kingdom will play our part in supporting Children in Need by taking on a Smiles and Miles Charity Challenge where we aim to complete a combined total of 10,000 miles and 1 million press-ups in a single day whilst raising funds for Children in Need.  

It will also be a competition to see which learner and which Military Academy raises the most money.

Our aim is to put our learners into a challenging environment whilst raising money to support every child in the United Kingdom so that they have the childhood they deserve – and the support they need to thrive. 

To create an event that has longevity to support learners’ awareness of their community needs.

Also, to develop social mobility through citizenship.
title: MPCT LCG Smiles & Miles Charity Challenge for Children in Need 2022

charity.name: BBC Children in Need
story:
Children in Need are a charity that raises money for disadvantaged children and young people in the UK. The end goal for Children in Need is to make sure that every child has a safe, happy and secure childhood.

This year Mondelez are making our fundraising bigger & better than ever! The team will be taking part in a 24 hour exercise endurance challenge with as many employees as possible getting involved! Yes that’s right you heard it Mdlz employees will be exercising all through the day and night at the office to raise money for this amazing charity.


What’s more, Mondelez will match the final amount we raise so your donations will be doubled!


Thank you for your generosity and wish us luck!


Team Mondelez UK
title: Mondelez 24HR Endurance Challenge page

pageSummary: The Inner Wheel Club of Wickford,  walk and talk because Children worldwide need supporting.
pageSummaryWhat: The Inner Wheel Club of Wickford,  walk and talk
story:
Members of Inner Wheel support friendship, personal service and international understanding. Children in Need is a very worthwhile charity for us to support, whilst we walk and talk!   Jayne and Chris have set themselves the challenge of walking 50 miles in 4 weeks, finishing on the weekend of November 18th, Children in Need Day.

They are counting their steps to make them count, building up the miles and money raised, to donate to Children in Need!

story:
I am  taking part in the Children in Need Big Learner Relay this year on Thursday 10 November.

I am driving the Ipswich to Colchester leg, starting at 08:00 at the Holiday Inn, London Road, Ipswich.

Some of us are taking pupils, some of us are driving solo…but we’ll all be in convoy…

I know that at the moment, money is scarce for everyone but could I ask for just £1 from you? I’ve donated my £1 (and  donated another £40 by buying a hoodie and flags for my car…

Thank you all in advance! 🙏

story:
Kayla would like to help support Children In Need charity this year. She is planning a walkathon around Haywood village on the Sunday 20th November 10.30am in fancy dress.


Supercharge your fundraising!Were so excited to let you know that the joint fundraising appeal with BBC Children in Need and Girlguiding is now open, so you can start having heaps of fun taking part!Were asking you, our amazing parents, young people, leaders and volunteers to Supercharge your fundraising by doing something you love, then making it longer, faster or bigger than ever before.Its important to us that everyone can take part so that every girl and young woman has a chance to do amazing things, whoever they are and wherever theyre from.Whether its a group of girls from your unit trying their favourite styles of dance, team football drill races, a walking or running relay, reading competition or doing a community clean-up, wed love to see it!This is how you can get involved:Choose an activity youll love doing. Think how you can supercharge it by getting together with friends or girls in your unit to make it longer, faster or bigger than ever before.Set

Every day, men and women have to leave their career in the Armed Forces as a result of physical or psychological wounds. 
Your fundraising helps them recover and get on with their lives. So far we've supported more than 25,000 people and won’t stop until every veteran gets the support they deserve.

charity.description:
Every day, men and women have to leave their career in the Armed Forces as a result of physical or psychological wounds. 
Your fundraising helps them recover and get on with their lives. So far we've supported more than 25,000 people and won’t stop until every veteran gets the support they deserve.
charity.name: Help for Heroes
story:
I’m proud to support Help for Heroes - because I believe our Armed Forces community should live well after service.

Can you imagine how tough life can be when a military career comes to an end, especially if it has been cut short by illness or injury. Overnight, you lose not only your job, but also a support network that is like family.

This is why I stand with Help for Heroes.

There are many ways the Charity helps veterans, their loved ones, serving personnel, and people who worked alongside the UK military. From helping people with their physical and mental health. To giving people the support, skills, confidence, and knowledge to make a success of life in the civilian world.

It’s an injustice that people don’t get a fair deal from the country they risked everything for. Help for Heroes won’t stop until those who served to keep us safe get the support they deserve.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

pageSummary: I am running the 2023 London Marathon because I want to support those who’s lives are affected.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the 2023 London Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: I want to support those who’s lives are affected.
story:
My Grampy had dementia at a very early age, eventually passing away at aged 63. Knowing the devastating impact this had on both him and my family I want to raise money in hopes of supporting Alzheimer’s Society in transforming the landscape of dementia forever. Until the day they find a cure, they will create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice. 

It has always been a person goal of mine to run the London Marathon, and with it falling on the 23rd April which is the anniversary of my Grampy’s funeral, running it this year and for the Alzheimer’s Society was an easy decision - the hard part is the training!

I know times are tough financially at the moment, any donation is so gratefully received, and if you cannot donate then sharing my page would mean just as much so that hopefully someone else can.

Follow my training over the next 6 months on my Strava and my tiktok: https://www.tiktok.com/@erinmarathon?_t=8WpQDopsqqT&_r=1 

Thanks,

Erin x
title: 2023 Marathon for Alzheimers Society

pageSummary: I'm running the Oxford Half Marathon because I want to raise money to support those affected.
pageSummaryWhat: I'm running the Oxford Half Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money to support those affected.
story:
Years ago, I lost my grandad Eddie to complications around Dementia. Now, my grandmother Pat is suffering the same terrible illness.

Whilst I was young at the time, the memories have stuck with me as I slowly watched a man I had a mountain of respect for slowly regress as a person.

My grandparents, Eddie & May, came over from Ireland - they were in every sense each others rock. They made a lot of my summers whenever I'd go and visit them in Liverpool. I remember every morning grandad or nan making me Egg in a Cup before my grandad would take his daily walk to see his daughters grave and pop into his other daughters houses' for a cup. He was also a huge figure in his community, something I didn't truly grasp the scope of until I saw his funeral turn out.

When his diagnosis came, my nan, also in her advanced age, looked after my grandad as best she could before my Auntie Kath stepped in to become my grandad's full-time carer. My Uncle Paddy also helped where he could whilst he dealt with his own ailing health. They suffered alongside my grandad, making sure he was never left wanting and always in as much comfort as possible until he left us.

Right now, my other grandad is looking after my nan, Pat, as she deals with the debilitating effects of Dementia. Nanny Pat & Grandad Joe had just retired and moved out of London where they'd raised their 4 sons and looked after their 9 grandchildren.

Not long after moving my nan slowly started to become ill with the effects of Dementia. She was always someone I knew to have a sharp mind, keeping up with mind games like her sudoku. I have memories of her telling me to stop back-seat solving her sudoku puzzles as she was solving them. It truly cemented to me how this disease can bring anyone under its shadow.

Nan and Grandad had planned to travel the world once they'd settled into their new home but that dream was taken from they because of this cruel and unfair disease. Instead now my grandad is carrying the burden of looking after his wife. Luckily my grandad has some professional support as well as his family around him but the emotional and physical toll is all the same.

I'm running to raise support for my grandparents and people like them who're dealing with this every minute of every day. Whether it's treatments or care, we need to take every inch we can against this disease.
title: Raising Funds for Alzheimer's Society

story:
Alzheimer’s Society is transforming the landscape of dementia forever.Until the day we find a cure, we will create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice.

I have never had good hand-eye coordination and have tried learning to juggle over the years but got frustrated and gave up. However as I have always wanted to learn, I am taking the 2 week challenge to learn to juggle for dementia in aid of the Alzheimer's society to help raise much needed funds and awareness to help individuals and their families who are going through a dementia diagnosis. Hopefully through fundraising, there will be better treatments and one day, a cure. Many thanks for reading, I hope you will consider supporting me in this challenge.

charity.name: Alzheimer's Society
story:
Many thanks for visiting our just giving page, and if you dropped by the Nowhere Café we hope you enjoyed your cake!

We’d also like to express our gratitude to BioCity & the lovely staff at the Nowehere café who made the event possible. We had great fun, particularly the dressing up bit, raising money for such a worthwhile cause.  

Alzheimers and associated diseases affect memory, thinking, language and mobility, primarily among older adults. Currently 900,000 people in the UK are living with Dementia with that figure expected to rise to 1.6 million by 2040. Overtime, symptoms worsen and people become increasingly more reliant on family and friends
for support. Although great steps have been taken, as yet no cure has been found.

Every penny donated will help the Alzheimer’s society fund research and importantly provide support for those living with Alzheimer’s and their families.

The Alzheimer’s Society is transforming the landscape of dementia forever. Until the day we find a cure, we will create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice.

story:
My Grandma, Mary Buckle, sadly passed away on 6 October 2022. Our family would like to raise as much as we can for Alzheimer’s Society in her memory. 

My Grandma was diagnosed with Vascular Dementia and we feel very fortunate that it didn’t progress as quickly as it can but not everyone is that lucky. Alzheimer’s Society provides support for people with all forms of dementia as well as funding research into this cruel illness.

pageSummary: We are raising money because this is a charity close to our hearts.
pageSummaryWhy: this is a charity close to our hearts.
story:
Carol Brown passed away peacefully on 15th October after a long struggle with Dementia. She was full of love and kindness for those around her, whoever they were, and had the most infectious smile that brought joy right to the end.

Alzheimer’s Society is here for everyone affected by dementia, aiming to ensure that people living with dementia today have the support they deserve, that their rights are protected and enhanced by campaigning, and that they can look to a brighter future thanks to investment in research.

The Alzheimer's Society Dementia Advisors have an extraordinary depth and breadth of knowledge. Combined with their dedication and compassion, they are unstoppable when it comes to providing personalised solutions that make a real difference to people with dementia and their carers. 

The Alzheimer's Society are a vital source of support and a powerful force for change for everyone affected by dementia. Help us to help this to continue by making a donation. 

Thank you so much for your contribution.

pageSummary: giving up alcohol and sugar because I see the impact of dementia every day at work
pageSummaryWhy: I see the impact of dementia every day at work
story: I'm taking part in Quit for a bit for Alzheimer's Society. Every pound I raise will help someone living with dementia. As a mental health nurse working on an older adult ward, I see the impact dementia has on the person and their loved ones every day. The condition causes so much pain and heartache, whilst a person slowly loses the parts of themselves that makes them who they are. Despite seeing the awful side of dementia, I also get to be part of improving someone’s quality of life and there are many services out there to support someone that need money to keep running. I hope there will one day be a cure to this awful condition and that can only happen if we continue to put money into research and improvements in dementia treatments.

pageSummary: I am raising money because I want to help raise funding and awareness.
